citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee does not have a current attending veterinarian (AV) employed under formal arrangements or a written
program of veterinary care for species covered by the AWA. The licensee conveyed that their attending veterinarian
recently moved farther away and they have been working to find another veterinarian that sees exotics and birds. The
licensee is obtaining veterinary care as needed and following their instructions, but needs to have a designated AV, site
visit, and develop a written program of veterinary care that includes regularly scheduled site visits. Having a current
attending veterinarian and a complete program of veterinary care is necessary in maintaining the health and well-being of
the animals.
***Correct by 7/19/24

At the time of the inspection, the licensee did not have a written contingency plan in place. A written
emergency/contingency plan is required to help ensure animal health and well-being in the event of an emergency or
disaster. Without this tool, animals may suffer illness, injury or death due to unpreparedness should an emergency or
disaster strike. The licensee must develop, document and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling,
treatment, transportation, housing and care of their regulated animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which
could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their
possession). The contingency plan must include all of the information and documentation as detailed in Section 2.134(a-
c) of the Animal Welfare Act and Animal Welfare Regulations.
***Correct by 7/19/24.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The licensee is missing a complete species-appropriate environmental enhancement plan that is required for regulated
birds. They are providing some enrichment to the birds including perches, toys, nest boxes, varied substrates, and items
to pull apart, but lack a written plan approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan, at a minimum, must address social
grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. A species-appropriate
plan for environmental enhancement is necessary to promote the psychological well-being of the birds on the premises.
***Correct by 7/19/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee does not have a current attending veterinarian (AV) employed under formal arrangements or a written 
program of veterinary care for species covered by the AWA. The licensee conveyed that their attending veterinarian 
recently moved farther away and they have been working to find another veterinarian that sees exotics and birds. The 
licensee is obtaining veterinary care as needed and following their instructions, but needs to have a designated AV, site 
visit, and develop a written program of veterinary care that includes regularly scheduled site visits. Having a current 
attending veterinarian and a complete program of veterinary care is necessary in maintaining the health and well-being of 
the animals.  
 
***Correct by 7/19/24 
2.134 
   
Contingency planning. 
At the time of the inspection, the licensee did not have a written contingency plan in place. A written 
emergency/contingency plan is required to help ensure animal health and well-being in the event of an emergency or 
disaster. Without this tool, animals may suffer illness, injury or death due to unpreparedness should an emergency or 
disaster strike. The licensee must develop, document and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, 
treatment, transportation, housing and care of their regulated animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which 
could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their 
possession). The contingency plan must include all of the information and documentation as detailed in Section 2.134(a-
c) of the Animal Welfare Act and Animal Welfare Regulations. 
 
***Correct by 7/19/24. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The licensee is missing a complete species-appropriate environmental enhancement plan that is required for regulated 
birds. They are providing some enrichment to the birds including perches, toys, nest boxes, varied substrates, and items

to pull apart, but lack a written plan approved by the attending veterinarian. The plan, at a minimum, must address social 
grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. A species-appropriate 
plan for environmental enhancement is necessary to promote the psychological well-being of the birds on the premises. 
 
***Correct by 7/19/24. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
